description: A development of quit, influence by Anglo-Norman quite.

definitionGroups.group: To the greatest extent or degree; completely, entirely.

entries.meaning: With verbs, especially past participles. [from 14th c.]
examples: Nobuyoshi Araki has been called a monster, a pornographer and a geniusâ€”and the photographer quite agrees.

entries.meaning: With prepositional phrases and spatial adverbs. [from 15th c.]
examples: Margaret passed quite through the pines, and reached the opening beyond which was what was once the yard, but was now, except for a strip of flower-border and turf which showed care, simply a tangle of bushes and briars.
It was almost quite dark in there and she kept her arms stretched out in front of her so as not to bump her face into the back of the wardrobe.

entries.meaning: With attributive adjectives, following an (especially indefinite) article; chiefly as expressing contrast, difference etc. [from 16th c.]
examples: When I warned him that his words might be offensive to identical twins, he said that identical twins were a quite different case.

entries.meaning: Preceding nouns introduced by the indefinite article. Chiefly in negative constructions. [from 16th c.]

examples: However, the proceedings were quite carefully orchestrated to produce what seemed to be a predetermined outcome.

definitionGroups.group: In a fully justified sense; truly, perfectly, actually.

entries.meaning: Coming before the indefinite article and an attributive adjective. (Now largely merged with moderative senses, below.) [from 17th c.]
examples: "My little plot has been rather successful, after all, hasn't it?" "Quite a perfect success," said Drake.

entries.meaning: With plain adjectives, past participles, and adverbs. [from 18th c.]
examples: London Underground is quite unique in how many front line staff it has, as anyone who has travelled on the Paris Metro or New York Subway will testify.

entries.meaning: Coming before the definite article and an attributive superlative. [from 18th c.]
examples: Scaramouche has already been greeted as the finest French Revolution yet brought to the screen-and even if you are a little weary of seeing a strongly American band of sans-culottes demolish a pasteboard Paris, you should not miss Scaramouche, for it is quite the best thing Rex Ingram has done since The Four Horsemen.

entries.meaning: Before a noun preceded by an indefinite article; now often with ironic implications that the noun in question is particularly noteworthy or remarkable. [from 18th c.]
examples: To debauch the Indians with rum and cheat them of their land was quite a Government affair, and not at all criminal; but to use rum to cheat them of their peltry, was an abomination in the sight of the law.

entries.meaning: Before a noun preceded by the definite article. [from 18th c.]
examples: His memoir features a child named Tommy Nothing Fancy who suffers from and dies of a seizure disorder. Quite the coincidence, don't you think?

entries.meaning: (now rare) With prepositional or adverbial phrases. [from 18th c.]
(especially Britain) To a moderate extent or degree; somewhat, rather. [from 19th c.]
examples: Mind your shoes, the basement is quite wet.

entries.meaning: (bullfighting) A series of passes made with the cape to distract the bull.
